http://i2.cdn.turner.com/money/galleries/2011/news/international/1102/gallery.new_arms_boom.fortune/images/lockheed_f-16.jpg
http://i2.cdn.turner.com/money/galleries/2011/news/international/1102/gallery.new_arms_boom.fortune/images/gem-t-missile.jpg
http://i2.cdn.turner.com/money/galleries/2011/news/international/1102/gallery.new_arms_boom.fortune/images/boeing_C-17.jpg
http://i2.cdn.turner.com/money/galleries/2011/news/international/1102/gallery.new_arms_boom.fortune/images/patriot_missile_system.jpg

In 2010, the Department of Defense announced overseas arms sales worth up to $103 billion. The deals aren't done, but they signal a bump in international revenues for American defense contractors. Here are some of last year's biggest authorizations.

150 AMRAAM missiles
Announced: December 2010
Destination: Switzerland
Manufacturer: Raytheon
Value: Up to $358 million

60 AH-64D Apache attack helicopters
Announced: November 2010
Destination: United Arab Emirates
Manufacturer: Boeing
Value: Up to $5 billion

12 MH-60R Seahawk helicopters
Announced: November 2010
Destination: Denmark
Manufacturer: Sikorsky Aircraft
Value: Up to $2 billion 

84 F-15 Strike Eagle jets
Announced: October 2010
Destination: Saudi Arabia
Manufacturer: Boeing
Value: Up to $29.4 billion

18 F-16 Fighting Falcon jets
Announced: Sept 2010
Destination: Iraq
Manufacturer: Lockheed Martin
Value: Up to $4.2 billion

209 GEM-T Missiles
Announced: August 2010
Destination: Kuwait
Manufacturer: Raytheon
Value: Up to $900 million

10 C-17 Globemaster III cargo planes
Announced: April 2010
Destination: India
Manufacturer: Boeing
Value: Up to $5.8 billion

Patriot Air and Missile Defense System
Announced: January 2010
Destination: Taiwan
Manufacturer: Raytheon, Lockheed Martin
Value: Up to $2.8 billion

http://money.cnn.com/galleries/2011/news/international/1102/gallery.new_arms_boom.fortune/index.html
